awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Fellow: Understanding scientists' views of good research practice
awd_abstract_narration:
General Audience Summary 

A post-doctoral research fellow will work under the guidance of the PI to carry out an analysis that will extract key concepts that scientists use to address questions regarding scientific integrity and good scientific practice. The fellow will analyze approximately 2,500 pages of transcribed interviews with scientists who work in academic and collaborative environments about their conceptions of good research practice and values such as applicability, risk, and responsibility. It is important to address these issues since scientists are increasingly compelled to communicate and publicly defend their standards and values regardless of whether they work in a more traditional academic environment or whether they are more strongly committed to commercialized science. The overall goal of this project is to facilitate these communication practices by bringing to light key conceptual tools to express, explain, critique, and defend their methodological standards and their values to different audiences. The results of this project may serve as a preliminary study for more in-depth analyses of communicating good research practice at the interface between science and broader publics. In addition, they will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate course, and they will be shared with other science educators.

Technical Summary 

The post-doctoral fellow will take a bottom-up approach to examine the methodological, epistemic, and ethical values that scientists consider crucial for their research, what attitudes they have toward these values, and what challenges they encounter when they explain their views of good scientific practice to others. The project is both timely and important. Very little is known about how scientists themselves conceptualize their views of good research practice and scientific integrity and about the conceptual challenges they may face in discussions about those issues. The fellow will draw on available interviews to provide numerous empirical examples of how scientists utilize and justify value statements in everyday research. By analyzing their views about collaborations, their merits and potential downsides, and particularly by assessing what motivations scientists identify for collaborative work, it will be possible to refine recent taxonomies of different forms of collaborative practices. In addition, the project will yield more information about what counts as replication in different scientific fields. Most importantly, it will provide deeper insight into the significance that scientists attach to the replication of experiments and to the communication of the outcomes of replications and about how they negotiate tensions between the perceived necessity to replicate findings and the perceived pressure to produce and publish novel and original results.

por.por_cntn:
Having a good understanding and firm conceptual grasp of research methodologies is an essential requirement for the effective functioning of peer criticism in science - for giving and receiving methodological and epistemic critique. This project studied how scientists conceptualize methodological and epistemic standards and values. To examine scientists' conceptions of good research practice, detailed interviews with 100 scientists (from the natural and social sciences) were analyzed. The ultimate goal of the project was to reveal and help remove communication barriers for interactions about methods, goals and values in collaborative research.

An analytic framework was developed to organize and categorize the rich qualitative information contained in the interviews while doing justice to the mixed and multifaceted concerns expressed by working scientists. The analysis of the interviews has exposed personal as well as conceptual obstacles for the functioning of peer criticism as well as for the communication within science about methodological issues more generally. These obstacles include perceived conflicts between good research practice and personal career goals; tensions between general ideas about methodologies, validation procedures, and the power of peer criticism and specific evaluation criteria for replications, pilot studies, research protocols, and responsible reporting; and the close association of failures with fraudulent practices. The analysis of scientists' views about methodologically sound research has suggested interventions that could be made in education to improve scientists' communication of methodological issues.

Modified by: Jutta Schickore
